image.altText: A man stands in a forest on a sunny day, looking into camera with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: Australia's largest super fund is investing money from its 'Socially Aware' option in the coal, oil and gas industries, despite excluding shares and corporate bonds of companies with fossil fuel reserves.

title.children: 'It looks like greenwashing': AustralianSuper's ethical option investing in coal, oil and gas industries

image.altText: Albanese wears a high-vis vest and white hard hat on a construction site with others.

props.synopsis: Amid growing pressure from state premiers, Labor's federal leaders will today decide the future of its links to the construction division of the CFMEU, which has been engulfed in scandals in recent days.

title.children: Federal Labor under pressure to cut ties with scandal-engulfed CFMEU

image.altText: A man smiles at the camera

props.synopsis: Officials and victims' loved ones gather near Amsterdam to mark the 10-year anniversary of MH17 being shot down, as Australian Attorney-General Mark Dreyfus tells the crowd the tragedy deepened the bonds between his country and the Netherlands.

title.children: 'I haven't lost hope': Memorial service held near Amsterdam to mark 10-year anniversary of MH17 disaster

image.altText: A composite of headshots of both men speaking at microphones.

props.synopsis: After once describing Donald Trump as "nuts" and a "traitor to the West", former prime minister Kevin Rudd has changed his tune.

title.children: After once calling Donald Trump 'nuts', Kevin Rudd has changed his tune

image.altText: Joe Biden speaks into a microphone at a lectern

props.synopsis: California representative Adam Schiff has joined a string of congressional Democrats publicly calling for Joe Biden to drop out of the election race, but the president says the only factor that would force him to let someone take his spot would be medical advice from a doctor. Follow live.

title.children: Pressure mounts on Biden as high-profile Democrat joins calls for president to drop out of race

image.altText: A screenshot of Thomas Sewell's suspended X account

props.synopsis: Neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell's X account has been suspended and a campaign under his name raising money for a "whites-only" community in regional Victoria has been disabled.

title.children: Neo-Nazi's social media suspension is only a drop in the ocean against extremism, warn experts

image.altText: A man celebrates winning a State of Origin match

props.synopsis: The Blues passed the ultimate test of their Origin mettle to win the decider at Lang Park and their reward is a place in New South Wales folklore.

title.children: How a blood-soaked try and unbreakable belief carried New South Wales to State of Origin glory

image.altText: Donny stares into the camera as he sits at the back of a bus wearing a yellow jacket, with antlers photoshopped behind him.

props.synopsis: The Bear has notched up a record number of nominations for a comedy, but it still trails Shōgun. Australians are also in the mix to pick up the world's top television award.

title.children: Here is the full list of Emmy nominees, with Shōgun, The Bear and Baby Reindeer on top and one more shout for The Crown

image.altText: Challicum Hills wind farm is a Pacific Hydro project

props.synopsis: As towers on Victoria's original wind farms approach the end of their life span, minds are turning to recycling options, especially for the tricky composite blades.

title.children: Is there a clean finish for a wind turbine at the end of its life? Not entirely

image.altText: A bespectacled Caucasian woman and her 10yo daughter each hold photos of a boy.

props.synopsis: Joey's family had just moved into their new rental home and were waiting for removalists to deliver their furniture, but when they arrived he had disappeared.

title.children: Joey Vines drowned quietly in a neighbour's pool. Years later, his family is finally smiling again

image.altText: Hobart's Cascade Brewery with a snowy Mount Wellington/kunanyi backdrop.

props.synopsis: Cascade Brewery was started by a swindler 200 years ago. It's now Australia's oldest brewery and workers are reflecting on its colourful history, including 15-minute beer breaks for workers and the bushfire that nearly ended it all.

title.children: 'I'd like a dollar for every photo taken': The 200-year history of one of Hobart's most recognisable attractions

image.altText: Man standing in front of river with leaves

props.synopsis: Faced with successive natural disasters, lifelong farmers are choosing to leave Queensland's 'salad bowl'. It has community leaders worried.

title.children: Faced with successive natural disasters, lifelong farmers are leaving this 'salad bowl'

image.altText: Simone leans over onto the beam and has a look of immense concentration, wearing a blue and red US leotard.

props.synopsis: Simone Biles is back as the one to beat at the Paris 2024 Olympics. A new documentary looks at her journey to the games, which start at the end of this month — including the aftermath of *that* Tokyo 2020 vault.

title.children: A new documentary looks at Simone Biles's mentality going into the 2024 Olympics

image.altText: A woman with windswept, dark hair wearing a black coat and white blouse turns a street corner with autumn foliage.

props.synopsis: Kathryn Hay is alleged to have punched her ex-partner Troy Shane Richardson in the face and verbally abused him during their relationship.

title.children: Former Miss Australia and ex-Labor MP in court over alleged abuse of then-husband

image.altText: A young family, mostly in light color sitting in a paddock where two emus roam in the background.

props.synopsis: Wombat joeys prance around Josh Neille's living room and young wallabies slide around on floorboards learning to use their long limbs. It's a sight now familiar to millions of people online.

title.children: Josh Neille's gritty care for rescued wildlife has made him a social media star and he's hoping to inspire others

image.altText: A woman holding a flame torch hands it to a man

props.synopsis: Modern Olympians might not compete naked or offer blood tributes to the gods. But there are a number of rituals you'll see at this year's Games that carry ancient religious roots.

title.children: The Olympics were banned because they were seen as a pagan cult. Then a conservative Frenchman revived them

image.altText: A close-up shot of a xxx-month-old baby wearing a white bucket hat, held by his father who looks into the camera..

props.synopsis: Territory Labor has promised to double the hours of free preschool offered to four-year-olds at some primary schools if it wins the upcoming NT election, billing it as a solution to cost-of-living pressures.

title.children: Early childhood policies spruiked as cost-of-living relief by Labor ahead of NT election

image.altText: a bald man smiles while strapped into a robotics machine

props.synopsis: The University of Canberra Hospital is now the second public health facility in the country to have robots helping with rehabilitation.

title.children: AJ lost the ability to walk earlier this year. Robots are helping him to get back on his feet

image.altText: A solider sitting at a drum kit.

props.synopsis: From symphonic wind to band and swing, through to jazz and rock. The Australian Army employs about 160 full-time musicians, whose duty is to entertain.

title.children: Making a living as a musician is no easy gig – so these performers turned to the Army

image.altText: Cyclist riding up a mountain, with a mountain range in the background, as cycling fans cheer from the side of the road

props.synopsis: Richard Carapaz has climbed his way to history, becoming the first Ecuadorian to win a stage at the Tour de France by taking honours on stage 17.

title.children: Carapaz climbs his way into history with Tour de France stage win

image.altText: A boy in a special bicycle next to two girls cycling and a woman pointing. Behind people on bikes

props.synopsis: After Harry Banks suffered a severe brain injury as a baby his parents thought special school would be his only education option. Twelve years later he is flourishing at his local mainstream school.

title.children: 'Valued': students with disability can thrive in inclusive mainstream classrooms

image.altText: Jarome Luai and Mitchell Moses embrace after the Blues won State of Origin III.

props.synopsis: Jarome Luai provides the Blues with the game-changing moment in their 14-4 win over the Maroons that clinches their first State of Origin series in three years, while a melee spills over the sideline and Billy Slater plays mind games before the match. Here are the five quick hits from a pulsating Game III.

title.children: Five quick hits: Luai steps up in Blues' Origin triumph, tempers flare and Slater throws pre-match curveball

image.altText: An aerial view of a hydropower dam among hills.

props.synopsis: Laos built about 80 hydropower dams on the Mekong River and its tributaries with the goal of becoming South-East Asia's "battery". But the revenue from the infrastructure is yet to flow through and the debt repayments are mounting up.

title.children: How close is Laos to going bust?

image.altText: A close up of fidgeting hands. In the background, a psychologist watches on, taking notes.

props.synopsis: Mental health problems can overlap with trauma, complex trauma and disability, making simple diagnoses and treatment difficult.

title.children: As DV incidents rise across the country, here's where new services will be available

image.altText: A male house sparrow, with brown and black markings around its face, sits on a tin fence.

props.synopsis: Sparrows are often considered pests, but a new study suggests lead levels in the birds’ blood could indicate if children in mining towns have been exposed to high levels of the poisonous chemical.

title.children: Sparrows accurately predict lead poisoning risk of children in Australian mining towns

image.altText: Composite photo of two men and one woman.

props.synopsis: More than 2,000 Palestinian refugees have made their way to Australia since the war in Gaza began in October last year. While relieved to have made it out, many are deeply pained by the fact they are now safe while many of their friends and family are not.

title.children: 'What have I done?' These families escaped the Gaza war but they're struggling with survivor's guilt

image.altText: Bill Shorten looks stern as he addresses the media

props.synopsis: Cabinet minister and former union leader Bill Shorten says he expects the ALP to ban all donations from the embattled CFMEU when the party's executive meets today.

title.children: Shorten says Labor will not be 'taking any CFMEU money anymore'

image.altText: A 3D model of the Trump rally shooting.

props.synopsis: To get a better understanding of the position of the shooter in relation to the US Secret Service snipers, the ABC has recreated the scene of the fatal rally in Pennsylvania.

title.children: Here's what 3D modelling reveals about what snipers could and couldn’t see moments before shots rang out

image.altText: Three men draped in Ukrainian flags smile at the camera in a field

props.synopsis: Russia and Ukraine have released a total of 190 captured soldiers in the latest prisoner exchange between the two sides, officials in Moscow and Kyiv have announced.

title.children: Russia and Ukraine each free 95 prisoners of war in third exchange in recent weeks

image.altText: A silhouette of a man, which does not show his face.

props.synopsis: A class action has been launched against Knowmore Legal, with sexual abuse survivors alleging the centre encouraged them to accept compensation payments that were lower than what they could have received.

title.children: Brian received just $40k after suffering horrific sexual abuse. He blames his lawyers for taking the deal

image.altText: A man in a suit with a bandaged ear

props.synopsis: The attempt on Donald Trump's life has strengthened Joe Biden's position when it comes to holding onto his party's presidential nomination. It has also weakened his chances of winning another four years in the White House as Republican voters are now hyper-motivated. But a Trump victory is not pre-ordained.

title.children: A Trump restoration is not guaranteed and the race for the White House will see more twists and turns

image.altText: A statue of a bull charging sits on a paved city street

props.synopsis: Financial markets are pricing in a victory for Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, with further all-time highs on the US stock market expected under a Trump presidency.

title.children: Who will be the next US president? The financial markets have a bet placed firmly on one candidate

image.altText: Uncontatced tribe on a beach

props.synopsis: The largest uncontacted tribe in the world has been filmed just miles from a number of logging concessions, sparking fresh calls from campaigners to protect the land.

title.children: New footage shows 'uncontacted' Mashco Piro tribe in Peruvian Amazon under threat of logging
